title: EU's MiCA regulation defers decisions on DeFi
originSummary: The European Union's Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCA) will not immediately affect decentralized finance (DeFi) protocols unless they are entirely decentralized, with no single controller.
Future regulatory decisions are postponed, indicating unresolved issues surrounding decentralized finance and platforms in the European Union.

The European Commission, according to the consultancy BCAS, is to produce an extensive report on DeFi's advantages and disadvantages within a year, which will define forthcoming actions for DeFi in the EU.
commentSummary: Cantor Fitzgerald, a financial services company, is exploring ways to improve its profitability via partnerships and the creation of unique products and services underutilized by its immediate competitors.
Leveraging its grasp of security-based swap regulations, Cantor Fitzgerald is introducing new initiatives such as the Cantor Swap Book.
With these new product offerings, Cantor Fitzgerald aims to pose a substantial challenge to the dominance of larger firms in the industry.

title: What is the impact of the recast EU Transfer of Funds ...
originSummary: The EU Transfer of Funds Regulation has been recast to include the Travel Rule for crypto-asset transfers, a crucial measure in combating money laundering.

The Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCAR) and revised Transfer of Funds Regulation (TFR3) were published by the European Commission in June 2023, and require all crypto transfers to comply with the Travel Rule, a stricter requirement than FATF's €1,000 threshold.

The TFR3, effective from 30 June 2023 and expected to be implemented from 30 December 2024, poses implementation challenges for service providers due to its demand for significant operational resources.

title: Crypto Regulation in Europe: ESMA Statement Clarifies ...
originSummary: The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has clarified the implementation timeline for the Regulation on Markets in Cryptoassets (MiCA), the EU's first uniform regulatory code for crypto-assets.

Certain stablecoins will be governed by new provisions from 30 June 2024 and other crypto-assets will fall under this regulation from 30 December 2024. ESMA is urging all relevant entities to begin preparing for this transition.

The statement alerts holders and clients of Crypto Asset Service Providers (CASPs) that the protections offered by MiCA may not come into effect until as late as 1 July 2026 if member states utilize grandfathering provisions for existing issuers and CASPs.
commentSummary: The article speaks about the deteriorating condition in Venezuela due to food shortage, political instability, and soaring inflation, leading many to resort to urban farming for survival.
Bartering's popularity is on the rise as locals begin to exchange goods and services amidst the worsening crisis.

Large corporations like Kellogg and Clorox are withdrawing their investments, indicating the possibility of Venezuela being pushed into a dual economy system: the affluent dealing in dollars and the poor resorting to bartering and self-sustenance through farming.

title: European Trilogue Session on EU AI Act Concludes with ...
originSummary: European negotiators are yet to agree on classification rules for high-risk Artificial Intelligence (AI), although a consensus was reached on Article 6 of the draft AI Act.

Uncertainty looms around certification regime for high-risk AI systems, which AI system qualifies for exemptions, and criticisms have emerged about companies determining their own AI systems' risk-level.

Further issues remain regarding the utilization of AI in law enforcement and the definition of AI, potentially delaying the AI Act's implementation until 2024 if no agreement is reached in the next negotiation session in December 2023.

title: Progress for AI Regulation in the EU; Spotify Exceeds Q3 ...
originSummary: EU lawmakers are progressing in creating regulations for artificial intelligence (AI), particularly with Article 6 of the draft AI Act.
Spotify, the music streaming giant, surpassed third quarter predictions, achieving roughly £56.5m of net income on £2.9bn revenue, largely due to cost-cutting and pricing increases.
Vinted, a Lithuanian e-commerce platform, is contemplating a secondary share sale exceeding £174m while launching its product verification service.
commentSummary: A survey by Autodesk and The Manufacturer magazine suggests a deficiency in provision of technical skills training in the manufacturing sector.
This Lack of technical training could lead to a "productivity pit", a situation where there's an insufficiency of skilled labor to uphold existing production levels.
According to the survey, 59% of participants consider the skills shortage a major issue, with 58% of participants confirming their companies are not adequately providing technical training.

title: EU lawmakers make progress in crucial talks on new AI rules ...
originSummary: European Union (EU) legislators have agreed on a key element of new regulations concerning artificial intelligence (AI), taking a significant step towards the comprehensive AI Act.
This progress comes after two years of debate and a draft bill approval in May that now awaits final sanction through more discussions.

The recent negotiations focused on the management of high-risk AI models and the consideration for exceptions in specific use-cases. The aim is to finalize by early December to prevent the discussions from extending into 2024 due to imminent elections.
commentSummary: Durham University has acquired the £40m Ogden Centre for Fundamental Physics, enriched with high-performance computing capabilities.
The Centre will be dedicated to studying the Universe's origins and the enigmatic dark matter.
The high-tech facility represents a significant investment in advanced astronomy and physics research.

title: Europe Daily News, 25 October 2023Perspectives & Events
originSummary: The General Court has overturned a previous decision that claimed the BEH Group abused its dominant market position by denying gas infrastructure access in Bulgaria.

The European Commission has approved TPG and Francisco Partners' acquisition of New Relic while also announcing upcoming meetings and regulations concerning various sectors. Astoundingly, new EU rules pertaining to packaging, consumer protection, and digital markets are in the pipeline.

In a significant development, the EU and Namibia have discussed a strategic partnership regarding sustainable raw materials and green hydrogen, whereas the EU and Bangladesh have secured a €400 million deal for renewable energy. The court has also pronounced judgment on a case tied to the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

title: EU Council Adopts Regulation to Promote Sustainable ...
originSummary: The Council of European Union has greenlit a regulation establishing a European green bond standard. This aims to provide uniform conditions for issuers opting for eco-friendly bond labels.

This new standard is designed to streamline the recognition of European green bonds aligning with the EU's taxonomy. Green bonds fundamentally invest in green technologies, resource efficiency and sustainable transport infrastructure.

The initiative intends to standardize the green bond market by incorporating a registration system and oversight framework, enabling comparable consistency. It also targets to combat greenwashing by setting voluntary disclosure requisites for green bonds and sustainability-linked bonds within the EU.

title: EU enables coordinated export controls by compiling national ...
originSummary: The European Commission has published an aggregation of EU Member States' national export control lists to improve the coordination of export controls across the EU.
Included in the list are Dutch controls on semiconductor manufacturing equipment and Spanish controls on quantum computing and other upcoming technologies.

This compiles with the EU’s Dual Use Regulation instituted in 2021 to manage export controls on items not universally agreed upon. The list will keep evolving as Member States inform the commission of refreshed or amended export control measures.
commentSummary: The article highlights increased state funding for infrastructure development, particularly in the transport sector, and the resulting benefits.
It emphasizes on the Nairobi Metropolitan Services Improvement Project, demonstrating how government funding has enhanced service access for 3.3 million individuals.
Developments in facilitating trade and cross-border transactions due to this funding are also explored.

title: Commission adopts new ETS Union Registry Regulation for ...
originSummary: The European Commission has introduced a new Extended Emission Trading System (ETS) Union Registry Regulation, part of the Fit for 55 legislative package aiming to reduce EU emissions by 55% by 2030.
The amendments will encompass maritime transport starting 2024 and establish a new emissions trading system for sectors like buildings, road transport, and others from 2027.

The regulation, encompassing changes to compliance dates, transparency, and market integrity and introducing simplification measures, is currently under examination by the European Parliament and Council, and is expected to be enforced by year's end, in the absence of objections.
